article.title: Solving the Vlasov equation in two spatial dimensions with the Schrödinger method

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the panels in Figure 1 illustrate?
choices: The distribution of dark matter in the Milky Way Galaxy.
The evolution of a dark matter halo over time.
A comparison between results from a Vlasov solver and the Schrödinger method in two dimensions.
The formation of large-scale structure in the early Universe.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of the point-like singularities in the phase φ/˜  (lower right panel)?
choices: They represent numerical errors in the simulation.
They correspond to regions of high density in the dark matter distribution.
They are the analogues of microscopic vorticity in the Schrödinger method.
They indicate the formation of black holes within the simulation.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the quantity δK represent in Figure 3?
choices: The difference between the kinetic and potential energies in the simulation.
A measure of the numerical accuracy of the Schrödinger-Poisson equation solver.
The rate of change of total energy in the simulation.
The deviation of the simulation from the concordance cosmological model.
The evolution of the Husimi distribution over time.
The relationship between the Husimi distribution and the coarse-grained Vlasov distribution.
The definition of the quantum pressure term in the Schrödinger method.
The derivation of the Madelung-Poisson equations from the Schrödinger-Poisson system.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the key advantage of using Equation (33) to calculate moments in the Schrödinger method?
choices: It allows for the direct computation of the phase space density.
It avoids the need for expensive velocity space projections.
It eliminates the occurrence of shell-crossing singularities.
It simplifies the numerical implementation of the Schrödinger-Poisson equation solver.
